      • houseboatonstyxb says:
        June 6, 2016 at 6:36 am

        Disclaimer. Further down (I think it’s in this OT) I’ve read something that sounds similar to my comment, but takes the ‘hateful is as hateful does’ quite seriously — stretching ‘hate’ to the same degree of meaninglessness as ‘racism’.

        I think ‘GOP war on women’ is a convenient metaphor for a great many proposed laws that came along at the same time, but of course it doesn’t mean that the GOP has the same feeling about women as some citizens really have against some opponents in a real war. (These GOPs seem to think they’re protecting women, or something.)

        The people on the Left that I normally read may use ‘hate/phobia’ as a convenient term for lumping together some Republicans’ apparent callousness or mild Schadenfreude, or political actions that might be motivated therefrom. But to use it more seriously — whufff.

    • Nita says:
      May 31, 2016 at 6:17 am

      (Oh dear, I’m late to the party. Thanks for the lonely representation, Dahlen!)

      First, some definitions, for the sake of clarity.

      i. By “conservatives” I’m going to mean mainstream, moderate-ish conservatives. Neo-monarchists, white nationalists, Vox Day et al. will not be included.

      ii. Similarly, communists, SJWs, left-anarchists et al. will be excluded from the comparison group of “liberals” (called “liberals” because “progressives” would be even more confusing).

      iii. Libertarians will not be included in either group.

      So, do I feel like “conservatives” are more hateful than “liberals”? Not by a large margin, but yes. I think this is due to two reasons:

      1. Conservatives generally tend to support more hawkish, tough-sounding and xenophobic* policies, which go quite well with angry rhetoric. “Bomb them back to the Stone Age” and such. In contrast, liberals are often stereotyped as being all about singing Kumbaya (which, ironically, is a prayer song).

      * that is, unfriendly to people from other ethnic groups, tribalist in the original sense

      2. Conservatives often hold beliefs that would lead to terrible treatment of vulnerable individuals if widely accepted, so their attempts to popularize such beliefs is perceived as hateful. E.g., when pope Francis said,

      “Let’s think of the nuclear arms, of the possibility to annihilate in a few instants a very high number of human beings. Let’s think also of genetic manipulation, of the manipulation of life, or of the gender theory, that does not recognize the order of creation.”

      he probably was not trying to incite hatred and violence against trans people. But if gender theory is like nuclear arms, what would disarmament look like?

      So, what “other results” do I get out of this? Not much. I suspect a large part of it is psychological** — and since we’re not going to kill off everyone with a conservative-leaning mind (right?), we’ll have to find a societal set-up that supports congenial coexistence despite these differences in temperament.

      ** E.g., Eggo upthread describes thinking of some guy as a “slovenly, glassy-eyed creature” and a “brainless thing“, while still considering himself a liberal. I’d say those thoughts have a distinctly conservative flavour (the liberal-flavoured equivalent would call the dude “toxic” or even “evil”, but not “slovenly” or a “creature”).

      • Ptoliporthos says:
        May 31, 2016 at 8:57 am

        Just so we’re clear, “Bomb them back to the Stone Age” is a quote from General Curtis LeMay, who served as USAF Chief of Staff in the Kennedy and Johnson administrations and was George Wallace’s running mate. I’d say he qualifies as mainstream left.

          Also, Wikipedia says:

          Curtis Emerson LeMay (November 15, 1906 â€“ October 1, 1990) was a general in the United States Air Force and the vice presidential running mate of American Independent Party candidate George Wallace in the 1968 presidential election.

          The American Independent Party (AIP) is a far right political party of the United States that was established in 1967

          Bonus:

          Wallace hoped that southern states could use their clout to end federal efforts at desegregation. His platform contained generous increases for beneficiaries of Social Security and Medicare. [..] “Wallace described foreign aid as money ‘poured down a rat hole’ and demanded that European and Asian allies pay more for their defense.” [..] “His startling appeal to millions of alienated white voters was not lost on Richard Nixon and other GOP strategists. “

          By that standard, I guess Trump is the modern mainstream left?

          • Ptoliporthos says:
            May 31, 2016 at 3:15 pm

            The central example of a liberal from the 1960s was firmly and flamboyantly against the Vietnam war.

            Okay, so Kennedy, Johnson, and Humphrey were on the right? Only the self-styled counter-culture constituted the mainstream? This does not compute for me.

            I noticed the ellipsis is Nita’s Wikipedia quote should be filled with this:

            Wallace’s foreign policy positions set him apart from the other candidates in the field. “If the Vietnam War was not winnable within 90 days of his taking office, Wallace pledged an immediate withdrawal of U.S. troops …

            That’s neither firm nor flamboyant enough to count, of course. But outside of identifying Wallace’s support for segregation as the “Hate” characteristic which, for you, marks him part as of the right, what other policy positions make him part of the right? Please persuade me.

            I think there’s a reasonable case to be made that Trump is mainstream left, for America at least. Certainly he’s not part of the Goldwater/Reagan/Bush continuity of the American right, that’d be more like Jeb Bush, Rubio, or Cruz. He’s more like the rust-belt pro-labor nationalist Pat Buchanan type. Nobody from that wing of the GOP has made it out of the primaries before.

            As for Cruz suggesting that he might bomb ISIS back to the Stone Age, it’s not like that isn’t the current President’s policy. Is Obama a creature of the right, or is bombing America’s adversaries back to the Stone Age a bipartisan mainstream policy? I think it’s the latter.

          • John Schilling says:
            May 31, 2016 at 5:21 pm

            itâ€™s not like that [bombing ISIS back to the stone age] isnâ€™t the current Presidentâ€™s policy

            That, in fact, is not the current President’s policy. The current President’s drones spend most of their time circling, fully armed, over decidedly post-stone-age infrastructure and conspicuously not destroying it. Even allowing for the usual level of hyperbole associated with the phrase “bomb them back to the stone age”, this isn’t it.

            Operation Linebacker II, with a bit of exaggeration, was an attempt at “bombing them back to the stone age”. Current US drone strikes are as close to being the polar opposite of “bombing them back to the stone age” as can be implemented while still occasionally having a bomb fall upon an enemy.

      • Jiro says:

        Conservatives often hold beliefs that would lead to terrible treatment of vulnerable individuals if widely accepted, so their attempts to popularize such beliefs is perceived as hateful.

        “Outgroup X holds beliefs which would lead to suffering. Thus outgroup X is perceived as hateful” could be said no matter what outgroup X is.

        Also, you’re equivocating between “conservatives are more hateful” and “conservatives are seen as more hateful”.

        • Nita says:
          May 31, 2016 at 4:53 pm

          outgroup X is perceived as hatefulâ€ could be said no matter what outgroup X is

But I think the case is more easily made about some groups (e.g., revolutionary communists, the Westboro Baptist Church) than about others (pacifists, Quakers).

          youâ€™re equivocating between â€œconservatives are more hatefulâ€ and â€œconservatives are seen as more hatefulâ€

          Well, Agronomous did ask 1) whether I think of hate as a common characteristic of conservatives, and 2) what my reasons for thinking that might be. Disentangling The Pure Truth from bias is beyond the scope of my answer.

      • Jiro says:
        May 31, 2016 at 10:32 am

        Selected books for sale on Amazon (having received ten or more reviews) with â€œLeftâ€ or â€œthe leftâ€ in the title:

        Do you understand the difference between “some people hate the left” and “people particularly hate the left”? Showing that people hate the left doesn’t show that the left is hated more than everyone else. For that you need to do a comparison. Are you trying to say that there are lots of anti-left books but no anti-right books? Or are you just taking a list of anti-left books and assuming, without checking, that this is something that only happens to the left rather than something which happens to everyone?

    • Corey says:
      May 31, 2016 at 11:34 am

      I’m a liberal, but take seriously to heart the Less Wrong lesson that there are no evil mutants. But few people in general (outside these comments) hold to that very well, so in many cases I think it’s just liberals evil-mutant-ing conservatives. I also have to work with some conservatives, which helps me see the nuance in views, OTOH being US Republicans they get a lot of info from inside the right-wing reality bubble, so communicating on some issues is awkward or impossible (like discussing paleo-anthropology with a young-Earth creationist, something that’s also happened to me at work).

      OTOH, assuming we’re talking about US Republicans here, it’s easy to interpret the opposition to immigration and homosexuality as hatred of those people. I have a pet theory about the widespread homophobia: conservative men who are anywhere but Kinsey 0 fall prey to bi-invisibility bias and typical-mind fallacy, believing that all men are secretly 100% gay, and so if the social sanction against homosexuality goes away, society will collapse. Explains the steady trickle of “anti-gay preacher caught with rentboy” revelations.

      In trying to understand anti-immigration views as something other than visceral hatred, I struggle. There’s some religious opposition – don’t want too many Muslims in a democracy because they’ll undermine the One True Religion of Christianity. That’s easily understandable even if I don’t agree.

      But the most principled justification I’ve heard from conservatives themselves is that we have to preserve “American culture” from dilution. The problem I have with this is: how would we even define American culture? What immigration policies are there that are eroding American culture, and what about it that’s important is being eroded? I can’t think of anything here except whiteness, and liberals tend to not value whiteness as an end in itself.

      • Psmith says:
        May 31, 2016 at 12:09 pm

        What immigration policies are there that are eroding American culture,

        De facto allowing lots of it from Third World countries.

        and what about it thatâ€™s important is being eroded?

        High-trust society (see Putnam) and, correspondingly, personal freedom and social capital. Electoral effects of new citizens who want different policies–both the first-order effect in which, for example, Mexican immigrants to the US turned California from a red state to a blue one and the higher-order effect in which we see a return to ethnic bloc voting across the political spectrum. Hell, most people just like being around people like them, and that’s just as true for white Protestant working class family men as it is for, say, SSC readers. Perhaps more controversially, /waves hand in the general direction of Jayman’s blog

        I canâ€™t think of anything here except whiteness, and liberals tend to not value whiteness as an end in itself.

        No kidding.

        • Corey says:
          June 1, 2016 at 11:48 am

          High-trust society (see Putnam) and, correspondingly, personal freedom and social capital.

          Is this the idea that, say, if we got a buttload more Mexican immigrants then our police would become as bad as Mexico’s? Seems like a stretch – path dependency is a powerful force. Also Mexico has 1/3 of the population of the US, so even if the whole country moved here, we’d be 1/4 Mexican overall.

          Electoral effects of new citizens who want different policiesâ€“both the first-order effect in which, for example, Mexican immigrants to the US turned California from a red state to a blue one and the higher-order effect in which we see a return to ethnic bloc voting across the political spectrum.

          In a two-party system, if one embraces white nationalism, we pretty much have to have ethnic-bloc voting. (Raising interesting questions of how the white nationalists, religious folks, and fiscal conservatives would ally in a parliamentary system)

          And to be fair, that’s why Israel can’t give the franchise to Palestinians – they want to remain Jewish, so you can’t allow a non-Jewish electoral majority.

          Hell, most people just like being around people like them, and thatâ€™s just as true for white Protestant working class family men as it is for, say, SSC readers. Perhaps more controversially, /waves hand in the general direction of Jaymanâ€™s blog

          That’s exactly the thing conservatives are claiming to be misunderstood about – they complain that liberals think they want to restrict immigration for racist reasons, to keep America white. (Assuming the blog is HBD) If that’s the real reason, then fine, but conservatives should own it. (To be fair, ones around SSC tend to actually own it).

          • Psmith says:
            June 1, 2016 at 12:25 pm

            Is this the idea that, say, if we got a buttload more Mexican immigrants then our police would become as bad as Mexicoâ€™s?

            Partly, although it would take a few generations. But Putnam’s book is called Bowling Alone, not Bribing Cops. Loss of social cohesion by way of increased diversity doesn’t just hurt government institutions. It also hurts community by thinning or tearing the web of voluntary associations that historically made up a good deal of American civic life.

            There’s also crime. Crime rates of Mexican immigrants are disputed and hard to come by, but many people who oppose immigration believe as a matter of fact that illegal immigrants commit crimes at a rate greater than the relevant national averages, and they’re not obviously wrong. In any case, most restrictionists will argue that nations are not obliged to let anyone move in who isn’t clearly likely to be a net benefit in terms of crime, earning potential, and so on. So even if immigrants were just as criminal as the existing national population, one restrictionist case would be to keep the bottom quartile out, say.

            Also Mexico has 1/3 of the population of the US, so even if the whole country moved here, weâ€™d be 1/4 Mexican overall.

            I think it’s probably more obfuscatory than revelatory to assume that Mexicans obey the ideal gas law.

            they want to restrict immigration for racist reasons, to keep America white.

            A rough taxonomy: there are people who think this for terminal reasons (~white identity and the like), there are people who think this for instrumental reasons (social cohesion, HBD), there are people who think this for one reason or another but wish to advocate their preferred policies while staying within the Overton window, there are people who are quite happy with non-white immigration as such but would prefer to exercise control over the borders to ensure that we get more Chinese programmers and Indian doctors and fewer Mexican campesinos, and there are people who’d be happy to take the Mexican campesinos but would prefer that they speak English, give their children English names, and otherwise work harder to assimilate.

        • Cerebral Paul Z. says:
          June 1, 2016 at 11:54 am

          It always surprises me a little when I see people openly arguing “we need to keep these people out because they won’t vote the way I want”. It’s always struck me as the sort of thing someone might secretly believe but would be ashamed to say out loud.

          • Corey says:
            June 1, 2016 at 12:04 pm

            That’s literally the argument often presented on, say, gerrymandering and hurdles to voting. (Not always; sometimes people claim to have higher-minded reasons, or oppose universal democracy for other reasons).

            In a partisan political system with elected officials making election law, we have to expect that. OTOH I don’t have a better way of dealing with election law – if I were king I’d no doubt be able to design fantastically representative and fair elections, but what’s the point if there’s a king?

          • Psmith says:
            June 1, 2016 at 12:37 pm

            Itâ€™s always struck me as the sort of thing someone might secretly believe but would be ashamed to say out loud.

            What about when people say “we need to let these people in because they’ll vote the way I want”?

            (“Permanent Democratic majority”, etc.).

          • David Friedman says:
            June 1, 2016 at 12:41 pm

            “but would be ashamed to say out loud.”

            Why? It looks to me like one of the more defensible arguments.

            1. People want to move from Mexico here because the U.S. is a much more attractive society.

            2. Part of the reason it is more attractive is that our governmental system is in various ways better.

            3. Voting can change the governmental system, so …

            4. If we let in a lot of the sort of people who have caused Mexico to have a much worse government, they might vote to make our governmental system much worse.

            The argument may well be wrong, but I don’t see why it is shameful. It seems to me that “if they come, my neighbor will hire one of them instead of one of me, and I want to stop that from happening” is a more shameful argument than “if they come, they will change the government that rules me in ways I don’t like.”

          • Cerebral Paul Z. says:
            June 1, 2016 at 7:58 pm

            Short, glib answer to David Friedman: Mexicans who come here are going to be voting for the Democrats, not the PRI. If electing Democrats were capable of making the US significantly more like Mexico, we’d have heard about it before now.

            Longer answer: I’m thinking here of procedural norms which most people regard as overriding whatever moral necessity there may be in electing their own guys. Even someone who believed that Obama is a Kenyan agent of radical Islam would probably not declare himself willing to steal an election to keep Obama out. Pace Corey, I don’t recall anyone saying openly that their purpose in supporting, e.g., voter ID requirements is to suppress the other side’s legitimate turnout; even if it were the real motive (I don’t believe it usually is) I wouldn’t expect anyone to admit it, even to themselves; it’s too open a violation of the ground rules. So: I expected that people would regard the idea of manipulating immigration quotas to benefit their own party in the same unsavory light. I may have been wrong: like I said, I’ve been surprised a few times.

          • onyomi says:
            June 1, 2016 at 9:43 pm

            “If electing Democrats were capable of making the US significantly more like Mexico, weâ€™d have heard about it before now.”

            Been to Detroit? Food’s not as good, though.

          • Cord Shirt says:
            June 1, 2016 at 10:06 pm

            Whether the argument sounds bad depends on your baseline assumption. Is the baseline to let everyone in? Then “we should make an exception for people who won’t vote the way I want” sounds bad. Is the baseline to let no one in? Then “we should make an exception for people who *will* vote the way I want” sounds bad.

          • Corey says:
            June 2, 2016 at 10:53 am

            @Cerebral Paul Z: What has happened with voter ID is in fact a little bit dissimilar to openly expressing the motive is to push down turnout: lawmakers supporting it are on record predicting/asserting that it will push down turnout and that the resulting reduced turnout will be to Republican advantage. Which is still a consistent position to hold while saying “it’s all about security” or whatever.

            And to be fair to them, it’s impossible to make any change to election laws/procedures that doesn’t have *some* partisan effect. And such effects are usually demographically predictable.

          • Corey says:
            June 2, 2016 at 11:00 am

            @onyomi: Ah, the old “Democrat-run cities” trope. Approximately all cities are Democrat-run; Republicans took the “rural” side in the culture wars.

          • Corey says:
            June 1, 2016 at 12:00 pm

            Do you think there’s not a reality bubble, or that there’s an equivalent one on the left? Surely you have relatives and high-school acquaintances on Facebook who can dispel that notion.

            People sitting in cubicles next to me earnestly believe that European cities have “no-go zones” where non-Muslims are forbidden, for example.

            Most Romney voters think the stock market is down under Obama, despite it being easy to see that’s not true (maybe S&P itself and the WSJ are in thrall to the lieberal mainstream MSM media?)

            Another guy near me earnestly believes that the Iran nuclear deal was such a transparently bad idea that his grandchild will grow up speaking Arabic. (Iran speaks Farsi, but whatevs). Evil mutant John Kerry made this deal that he knew evil mutants the Iranians would break, dooming the world, in exchange for diplomatic cred.

            How many people believe that the military could have saved the ambassador in Benghazi, but evil mutant Obama ordered them to stand down so he wouldn’t be late for a fundraiser? These are not strawmen – real people earnestly hold these positions.

            I’ve seen lots of otherwise-rational people get sucked into this bubble, and have never witnessed anyone break out (I’ve heard online anecdotes of recovery, though).

            The methodology is simple: if a source contradicts conservative dogma, that in itself is enough to declare it untrustworthy. Therefore no trustworthy source contradicts conservative dogma, therefore it’s correct.

            Probably nobody *here* is trapped in a reality bubble, because that’s a huge failure of rationality. OTOH if you move in conservative circles surely you know some.

          • keranih says:
            June 1, 2016 at 12:03 pm

            Corey –

            We’ve had people posting here inside the last week who are obviously venturing outside their leftist bubbles for the first time. There are absolutely people on the left who live in an echo chamber.

          • Cerebral Paul Z. says:
            June 1, 2016 at 8:03 pm

            I think there’s widespread public ignorance among political believers of all stripes– and that (contrary to what the word “bubble” seems to imply) this is the natural and expected thing.

          • Corey says:
            June 2, 2016 at 10:58 am

            @Cerebral Paul Z: I disagree with what I think you’re implying, which is some sort of symmetry assumption. Just because everyone has some amount of politically-motivated beliefs, it doesn’t follow that the number / strength / tribal acceptance / distance-from-empirical-reality of such things is consistent amongst individuals or tribes.

            The distance from empirical reality is significantly greater for US Republicans than US Democrats.

          • Cerebral Paul Z. says:
            June 2, 2016 at 11:55 am

            Funny, I know people who are just as convinced that the Low Information Voter is found only on the left. Both beliefs are good examples of what happens when you take the facts of public ignorance and stir in a cup of confirmation bias.

          • David Friedman says:
            June 2, 2016 at 2:56 pm

            “The distance from empirical reality is significantly greater for US Republicans than US Democrats.”

            I’m unsure not only if it’s true but what it means. How do you add up different sorts of errors?

            Mr. R. mistakenly believes in creationism, a belief that has almost no effect on his life, correctly believes that sleeping with someone has a a strong effect on how you feel about that someone and that, for him and most other people, one implication is that monogamy works better, in the long run, than promiscuity.

            Mr. D correctly believes in evolution, is into hookup culture, is thinking of maybe someday finding a wife willing to join him in an open marriage.

            How do you decide whose distance from empirical reality is greater?

            Or, if you prefer, Mr. R doesn’t believe in evolution, correctly believes that there are substantial differences in the distribution of intellectual and psychological characteristics between men and women and among races as conventionally defined. Mr. D has the opposite view on both subjects.

            Does it count that Mr. R’s views are at least internally consistent, since God could, for his own reasons, have designed men and women differently, whereas Mr. D’s views require him to ignore the implications of selection for reproductive success?

          • Corey says:
            June 2, 2016 at 3:11 pm

            @David Friedman: I’m not speaking of moral-preference type stuff, but acceptance of false facts. Examples off the top of my head:

            – Obama or Clinton ordered the military to stand down in the Benghazi attacks (got this one again from an acquaintance at lunch today)
            – Global warming isn’t anthropogenic
            – European cities have “no-go zones” where Muslims rule and non-Muslims are forbidden
            – Obama is Muslim (most Trump voters believe this, before you dismiss it as “fringe”)
            – ACA death panels (I *hope* this went away since ACA actually went into effect)
            – Skewed polls (this claimed Karl Rove, master bullshitter, when he melted down on air when Fox called Ohio for Obama in 2012)
            – Romney in the “please proceed, Governor” moment in one of the debates (he was repeating some talking point about “they said Benghazi was over a YouTube video” and got debunked in real time)

            I’ll even spot you GMOs on the left. There’s a nontrivial hack gap, both on the ground and in the intellectual circles.

            June 3, 2016 at 9:52 am

            I live in NYC, the USâ€™s largest city. I donâ€™t know of any area where strangers are very well advised to stay out.

            Eh, we’re not as half bad as Baltimore but I wouldn’t recommend spending a lot of time in Washington Heights or my old neighborhood in the Bronx after dark. You can go nearly anywhere in the daylight but it’s not smart to wander around in certain neighborhoods after sunset.

            Also I thought LA was bigger than us? Or does that not count because they’re spread out so much?

          • Anonymous says:
            June 3, 2016 at 10:21 am

            I used to mentor a kid in East New York, not the nicest neighborhood in the world, but I never felt in much danger. Didn’t go there in the middle of the night though.

            More generally, the issues with East New York, Red Hook, South Bronx, etc. aren’t insider / outsider thing. Local residents are in as much danger as anyone else. They are just high crime neighborhoods.

            There are neighborhood in NYC that are far more ethnically homogeneous but don’t have any local code or are in any sense a no-go zone. A few of them are even made up predominately of Muslims (e.g. Astoria-Ditmars, Kensington).

            NYC has a larger population both in terms of official borders (8.4M v 4M) and metropolitan area (20.2M v 12.9 or 18.7M depending on definition).

          • John Schilling says:
            June 3, 2016 at 3:49 pm

            We have areas of cities in the USA which are under the sway of ethnic minorities and where strangers are very well advised to stay out. If youâ€™re going to tell me that there are no such areas in Europe I will laugh at you.

            “Well advised to stay out of” is a fuzzy enough standard as to be meaningless, but I lived as a middle-class white guy in south-central Los Angeles for the better part of a decade, specifically including the Rodney King beating riots, and there is no part of that city that I would describe as a “no-go zone” or where white people were “forbidden”.

            And I have read more accounts than I can count, by Americans who while in Europe specifically investigated alleged “no-go” zones and found them to be apparently peaceful ethnic neighborhoods where nobody tried to keep them out or harass them for their obvious misplacedness. Specifically including accounts by Americans who went as believers in “no-go zones” expecting to prove the existence of such zones and ending up acknowledging they were wrong.

            I have read no contrary first-person accounts. I believe you are wrong about this, and I await your laughter.

          • keranih says:
            June 3, 2016 at 5:28 pm

            @ John, others –

            I am willing to accept your stories of how things ain’t so bad. I am still required to balance those against discussions in the 1990’s with people both in the USA and abroad who told me directly to not go into specific areas of some cities. To be true, this was during the 90’s, when things were far worse.

            I did end up in some of those areas, being young and smarter than anyone else, and didn’t immediately get murdered. And I have lived in sketchy parts of smaller towns. Not places I would let my mother walk unattended, though. But “unsafe for my mother and niece to wander in” is not the same as “police no-go zone.”

            So, I am willing to give Corey this one.

          • Tom Womack says:
            June 6, 2016 at 8:49 am

            There are a couple of places in Central and Latin America where people who I know and who generally come across as thoroughly competent travellers report going into the wrong part of town and ending up mugged – Mexico City, Rio, bits of Buenos Aires. I had BA residents tell me “oh, I wouldn’t go there wearing that camera”, though the mugging was from a dodgy taxi driver and as harmless as armed robbery (it was a screwdriver, but about one size up from a watchmaker’s screwdriver) gets.

    • arbitrary_greay says:
      May 31, 2016 at 2:41 pm

      Oppressed minorities perceive actions against them to be a form of violence. The motivations behind such acts are characterized as hateful.

      The caricature of the rich old white dude callously ordering that some population be oppressed so he can keep eating caviar or something is hateful not because of the dude’s passion or particular emotion (it’s his lack of care for people that is his primary trait), it’s the action he is setting in motion.

      Such actions and rhetoric are perceived to be hateful because the oppressed population believes that there is another action the hateful person could be taking that does not oppress them, but still gets the oppressor what they want on an object level. (They could be making money through non-oppressive means.) In that sense, they perceive that the oppressor is going out of their way to be oppressive. So, hateful.

      Hate is divorced from anger for this definition, it’s about the “violence.” Hatred derived from indifference is considered the most insidious.

      • Deiseach says:
        May 31, 2016 at 6:21 pm

        I would accept your definition, arbitrary_greay, save that I have never seen anyone making the distinction between “hateful” and “hating/hater” that you posit here.

        I have seen plenty of bile about “they hate us, they hate you, they do this crap because they are hating haters who hate and want to destroy us all!”

        • arbitrary_greay says:
          June 1, 2016 at 12:10 pm

          Under this definition, there isn’t a distinction. The person doing hateful acts is a hating hater that hates people.

          This is not helped by their still using the terms with the anger connotations in other situations. Variation of the Worst Argument in the Worst, via inconsistent linguistic prescriptivism.
          “We’re re-defining hate to be consequentialist! But it’s also still about strong passionate negative feelings. Intent isn’t magic! The well-intentioned conservative is still a hater!”

    • Agronomous says:
      June 3, 2016 at 7:44 pm

  27. brad says:
    May 29, 2016 at 1:39 pm

    I’ve been listening to a a lot of radio recently and one thing I noticed is that the first person pronoun of choice for powerful people is ‘we’. Presidential candidates will say things like “we just clinched the nomination”, movie producers “we wanted Tom Cruise for the lead roll”, business leaders “we had a vision for a new product”, and so on. I understand no man is an island and everyone has staff, but it still seems a little odd to my ear.

    Does anyone know if this is a growing trend or is it just something I hadn’t picked up on before?

    • keranih says:
      May 30, 2016 at 7:42 am

      It’s not new – FDR used it in his fireside chats (most notibly the “fear itself” speech.) And English Royality has been noted for using it for some time.

      My thoughts are: firstly that English lacks some formal elements of speech that reportedly exist in other languages, so that we don’t have a separate way of saying “I report the word of God” or “As your king and ruler”, or other ways of conveying (near) absolute authority.

      Secondly, that in a democratic society (and most human groups) if one doesn’t have the support of a majority, it’s worth pretending that you do.

      Third, that this is context dependent – it’s not universal, and there are still places where using first person singular is a sign of more confidence and authority than using the plural.

      • houseboatonstyxb says:
        May 30, 2016 at 8:11 am

        @ keranih

        I’ve long heard ‘we’ used for personal modesty, as in Oscar acceptance speeches. It surprised me in 2008 to hear it from John McCain: “I’m humbled to announce that we now have all the delegates necessary for the nomination.” The ‘humbled’ in place of ‘proud’ or ‘honored’ surprised me more, and caught on quickly; Obama said he was ‘humbled’ to win the Nobel Prize.

        ETA: I always thought FDR’s “We have nothing to fear but fear itself” meant “We Americans”, not somehow himself personally. It implied “It’s you other Americans who fear the Depression; I’m the one who only fears the fear.”

        • keranih says:
          May 30, 2016 at 12:29 pm

          we used for personal modesty

          OTOH – and this is perhaps fitting for the American Memorial Day – the use of we –

          the royal we, the editorial we, and the we of a man with a tapeworm

          – is eschewed by military servicemen (mainly officers) of my acquaintance. To use it in a positive sense is to claim credit for what one’s subordinates actually did, and to use it in a negative sense is to avoid taking responsibility and stopping the buck.

    • Yakimi says:
      May 31, 2016 at 9:42 pm

      It’s not new at all.

      â€“Moldemort, 2007

  28. Ruprect says:
    May 29, 2016 at 1:26 pm

    I want to learn maths. I want to understand physics. I went to university to study maths/physics and passed my first year exams, but quit (for reasons largely unrelated to study), and went on to study history instead.
    Over the past decade, I’ve borrowed Road to Reality, by Roger Penrose, four times (different occasions), had it in my possession for probably a total of six months, as well as having the pdf for several years sitting on my laptop. Never got past the second chapter.
    Same thing for my books on introductory algebra, algorithms, and calculus. Just can’t get past the first chapter.
    Is there any way to tell if material is simply beyond you, as opposed to just being boring/irrelevant?

    Has anyone else here attempted to teach themselves mathematics as an adult (over 22)? What was your motivation? How successful were you?

    What would it mean to say that algebra is beyond you? That you don’t have the capacity to think abstractly? That you can’t hold terms in working memory?

    I don’t understand relativity. What does it mean to “not understand” something like that?

    • J says:
      May 29, 2016 at 3:13 pm

      Have you tried Feynman’s QED lectures? There’s also a book but I hear the videos are more entertaining. Also, I think of programming as “math that does things”, so perhaps that’s a way to get into math while building interesting things that use it. Hackerrank.com has a bunch of online challenges and ranking that make it easier to stay engaged, as well as a whole category for math related puzzles.

    • William Newman says:
      May 29, 2016 at 4:41 pm

      Do you know what you want to be able to do with the knowledge? Find a job? Understand Nature in general? Understand a representative set of interesting and nonobvious things in Nature? (E.g., how to very predict the motion of a planet from astronomical observations, and/or how to compute the location and strength of various spectroscopic lines?) Understand how to solve a modern interesting applied problem, like handwriting recognition or optimizing the layout of a circuit board or computing the illumination of a complicated scene in a computer renderer? Understand how to solve nontrivial pure theory problems, like why there is no closed-form quintic equation analogous to the quadratic equation, purely out of curiosity? Master the rough-consensus techie applied math toolkit (your calculus, plus linear algebra, Fourier analysis, statistics, programming skills at at least intermediate level, general approximation methods like perturbation theory and variational analysis…) in order to make your fortune solving problems (to be determined) which resist analysis by innumerate handwaving?

    • Pku says:
      May 29, 2016 at 4:42 pm

      In terms of understanding, there’s a huge difference in teaching yourself which is that no one’s forcing you to do the exercises. It goes both ways – you can think that something is beyond you until you do some exercises and get it, or you can think you get it, then get to the exercises and realize you don’t know how to do them.

    • Vitor says:
      May 29, 2016 at 4:57 pm

      I didn’t self-study math, but I did study computer science starting at the age of 25, so I know what it’s like to go into formal math with very rusty highschool knowledge. My motivation was passion for the subject for its own sake (I’m a theory guy).

      If you are serious about learning math, actually doing the work is important. Chew on the topic, think about the implications of what you’re reading. Don’t believe a theorem just because it’s stated in a book. Go at it adversarially, question every assumption, and make the book convince you the theorem has to be true. It’s ok and completely normal to be full of questions. Get used to being perpetually confused.

      This is hard work, much much more than inexperienced people expect. The sheer density of written math dwarfs any other kind of writing. According to the rhythm we had at uni, 100-200 pages of material can take more than a month of full-time work to get through. It’s easier to stick with it if you have some pet programming project where you can apply what you learn, or a particular theoretical question you’d like to answer for yourself, or at least understand how that kind of question could be answered in principle. Something that gives you a sense of focus and progress.

      To answer some of your questions: I would say material is (currently) beyond you if you are unable to break it down to a mechanical level, i.e. you sort of grok the idea of a theorem or algorithm, but can’t work yourself through the proof step by step, you need to handwave and take things on faith. Sometimes this means that things are kind of clear when you are looking at one little detail, but your vision becomes cloudy as soon as you zoom out and try to grasp the broader context. This is not an immutable personality trait nor an incurable condition, it’s just your current state of skill. Experienced mathematicians seem to be incredibly fast thinkers because they don’t usually work at this low level but think in higher level abstract patterns, but the point is that they can drop down and make all their handwaving rigorous if they ever need to. Over time you will get better both at the low-level mechanical stuff and holding complex ideas (with many intermediate steps, caveats etc) in your head. Working memory improves with training, and can always be complemented with pen and paper ðŸ™‚

      Edited to add: Also, as others have said, do the excercises! Put your knowledge and understanding to the test regularly.

      • William Newman says:
        May 29, 2016 at 5:26 pm

        I’d say do the exercises or at least something that forces you to engage with the material enough that you can’t fool yourself about understanding it, and that you become familiar with it in a practical way. I have spent a lot of time with self-taught Go players and self-taught computer programmers, and some time with self-taught robot builders too. In all three things, just attempting to do obvious natural things can give one reasonably good practice and feedback even without doing artificial exercises, and in my experience the difference between the people who practiced on exercises and people who just got their practice working through more natural obstacles is considerably smaller than the difference between people who’ve gotten a lot of practice and people who’ve merely studied a book.

    • Frog Do says:
      May 29, 2016 at 5:13 pm

      One tip I might suggest is to break down every proof and every technique into more and more pedantic bullet-point list possible, as if you had to teach it to someone with no prior knowledge of the subject. Then apply it to slightly different problems, to see where things stop working. This is how I approach lesson planning and research, anyway.

      Also, studying the history of math helps, learning why people wanted to solve particular problems, how various approaches develop.

  30. Anonymous says:
    May 29, 2016 at 1:11 pm

    Something that came up in the last Open Thread:

    The Greek economy is in the tank. If they were still using Drachmas, any German creditors would have already taken a haircut just be virtue of wanting Deutsch Marks but holding debt denominated in Drachmas, which have now weakened based on simple economic output disparity.

    I’m ignorant of most of how international monetary stuff works, so I’d love it if someone could explain to me why the lenders don’t just refused to negotiate loans denominated in anything but Marks, if they’re even marginally concerned that the Greek government might opt to inflate their debts away to some degree.

    (I note also that apparently full-anon @ gmail is banned now too)

    • brad says:
      May 29, 2016 at 1:35 pm

      Everything is open to negotiation. If the Mexican government wants to issue bonds in pesos it will have to pay a higher interest rate than if it issues them in dollars or euros. Likewise if it issues them under local (Mexican) law versus New York law. It is possible bond terms could be so unfavorable to buyers that no promised interest rate would be enough to get them to buy them, but usually there’s someone willing to take the bet given a high enough coupon.

    • youzicha says:
      May 30, 2016 at 1:08 pm

      There are definitely cases where a government will borrow money denominated in e.g. US dollars. On the other hand, the government might not want the additional exchange rate risk, and may be willing to pay additional interest to get a loan denominated in its own currency.

      Also, if a country really can’t pay, then it’s not so clear that a dollar-denominated loan is any better. A country can always just default on the loan, and then the creditors have no way to recover, so the creditors may well prefer that the debtor-country runs the printing press and pays them back something.

    • HeelBearCub says:
      May 31, 2016 at 12:12 am

      I made the comment, so I feel duty bound to reply.

      Sovereign debt (T-Bills in the U.S.) is always, or near always, issued in the official currency of the government. The government needs their official currency to finance their operations. If the Greeks issued debt in Marks, they would just need to turn around and trade the Marks for Drachmas. In addition, the reasons I mentioned in the other post vis-a-vis relative changes in sovereign economic outcomes, are also reasons why a country will highly favor issuing debt in their own currency.

      The negotiation that occurs is that the market sets the interest rate at which they will buy the debt (as others have pointed out.) If potential creditors judge Greek debt to be more risky than German debt, the Greeks will have to pay more in interest than the Germans. Interestingly, the fact that Greece was in the Euro before the debt crisis allowed them to borrow money more cheaply than they otherwise would have. On the margin, this almost assuredly contributed their problems, as they probably borrowed more than they otherwise would have.

      The other thing to keep in mind, is that this works both ways. If the Greek economy improves faster than Germany, Drachmas will strengthen, and the German investor gets a double win. It’s easy to play 20/20 hindsight and ask why anyone would invest in Greek Treasury Bills if Greece is going to tank, but of course it wasn’t an assured thing.

      • Anonymous says:
        May 31, 2016 at 11:09 am

        Thanks for your answers, everybody!

        So essentially what I take away from this is, it’s a gamble, but one where the lenders are the house and have the edge? In that case there must be a ceiling for willingness to lend, surely? Is that what’s going on with the Greek bailout, that no sane private individual wants to lend them money at any markup anymore and so institutions with the power to force political change have to go in?

        • HeelBearCub says:
          May 31, 2016 at 11:50 am

          itâ€™s a gamble, but one where the lenders are the house and have the edge?

          Mmmmmm, no. That’s not at all how I would think about it. Compared to gambling, there is no “house” here. If the Greek government defaults on their debts, they haven’t “won” a big score. Everybody loses in that scenario.

          Lending is, I believe, generally thought of as a way to make economies efficient. I have money (i.e. production in excess of my desire for consumption) but desire to have it later. You desire to consume more now, at the cost of consuming (relatively) less later. In lending to you, I let you consume more now, but I will get to consume more (than I would have) later.

          The market price is set by several factors, but I think they primarily revolve around how strong your desire is to consumer more now, and how likely I judge it that I will actually get to consume more later. And remember “more” is a relative measure, especially for the lender.

          So, in the case of US T-Bills, interest rates are very, very low and have been low for quite some time. In the wake of the crash of 2008 they sank much lower than they had before. You might think that a financial crisis would cause US T-Bills to require higher interest, but relative to every other investment option, including holding on to cash (other than the dollar) T-Bills looked like the best bet to generate “more” money.

          Side note: Holding on to U.S. T-Bills is always better than just holding on to dollars, because the US government can always print dollars. If you don’t want to hold T-Bills, you want to hold dollars (for the length of the term of the T-Bill) even less.

          • Murphy says:
            June 1, 2016 at 7:51 am

            It’s worth noting that during the financial crisis the return on US treasuries briefly dropped bellow the projected rate of inflation. People were literally paying the US government (a small amount) to hold their money since it was about the safest investment available.

            Of course when the market is in that state it’s actually a really good idea for the government to take on more debt. They’re being given effectively free money.

        • A Definite Beta Guy says:
          May 31, 2016 at 9:13 pm

          Yes, that’s more or less the case. Greece lost the ability to finance itself at anything besides usurious rates. It required a bailout from the IMF and the EU, which imposed austerity conditions upon Greece.

          It’s complicated, but to the extent it’s a gamble, it’s more a gamble for the lenders. Banks typically hold little capital. It’s the old “Your money isn’t really in the bank” trick…kind of. Banks are required to hold a certain amount of equity against their outstanding assets, but it’s risk-weighted. Against risky loans, you might hold 10% capital, but against Greek government loans, you might hold 2%.
          If Greece defaults, you might become insolvent. This is different than illiquid, but if people learn a bank is an insolvent, there’s a great chance of a run (and from what I understand, Europe did not have as much deposit insurance as the US…this taken from Bernanke’s recent memoir).

          • Steven says:
            June 1, 2016 at 1:17 pm

            “Against risky loans, you might hold 10% capital, but against Greek government loans, you might hold 2%.”

            Close, but not quite right.

            Under the (current version) international standard for bank regulation, the riskiest lending requires up to 9.5% common equity as a buffer. Earlier versions of the standard had lower requirements.

            The bonds of all EU governments (more precisely: the bonds of all BIS-member governments) have a risk-weighting of zero. Thus, a bank needs to hold 0% capital against any Greek government bonds, regardless of their credit rating. This has been true under all three versions of the Basel capital requirements (Basel I, II, and III for those who want to Google the details).

            Utterly unsurprising — under the guise of safety regulation, governments got together and and set an international regulatory standard that favors lending to governments over lending to the private sector, even when the governments in question are highly risky. Predictably, this led to excess lending to risky governments, making the banking system less stable.

          • John Schilling says:
            June 1, 2016 at 2:06 pm

            This is quite similar to what happened domestically in the US with regard to sub-prime mortgages.

            Step 1, declare a particular type of investment Extra Super Safe on account of people have historically almost never defaulted. Home mortgages, first-world government bond, perfect examples.

            Step 2, exempt from your Banking Must Be Heavily Regulated To Reduce Risk safeguards, the designated Extra Super Safe Investments, because bankers really want the leverage and if it’s Super Safe the risk is acceptable.

            Step 3, note that leveraged investment banking confers a powerful economic advantage on everyone involved, and it is unfair and discriminatory to exclude entire classes people (or nations) from that just because they historically tend to default on their debts…

            You’ll get no shortage of public and private actors trying to grab their share of that action, and if many of them privately understand where it will inevitably lead, it will lead there whether they grab their quick buck or not.

          • HeelBearCub says:
            June 1, 2016 at 2:09 pm

            Step 3, note that leveraged investment banking confers a powerful economic advantage on everyone involved, and it is unfair and discriminatory to exclude entire classes people from that just because they historically tend to default on their debtsâ€¦

            I don’t think the history of redlining supports this narrative.

          • Anonymous says:
            June 1, 2016 at 2:23 pm

            @John Schilling
            And now we are seeing the whole thing recapitulated again. The Dodd-Frank law had a section requiring mortgage lenders to have skin in the game. But under pressure from banks, real estate agents, home builders, older home owners looking to sell, and so on, they included an exemption from these requirements for Qualified Residential Mortgages. When the regs were written QRM turned out to be almost any mortgage, because those same lobbying forces put pressure on the CFPB and by the time they were written people had forgotten all about the housing crisis. House prices only go up, right?

          • John Schilling says:
            June 1, 2016 at 3:50 pm

            I donâ€™t think the history of redlining supports this narrative.

            Isn’t redlining considered unfair and discriminatory by just about everyone who cares about that sort of thing, and wasn’t it banned just about everywhere they came to power?

            My narrative absolutely does not have the bit where humanity is everywhere and always opposed to unfairness and discrimination and makes sure they never happen. I’m mostly into science fiction. not fantasy.

          • The Nybbler says:
            June 1, 2016 at 4:09 pm

            Redlining was a practice of the Federal Housing Administration that was ended long before the 2008 crisis. It had to do with particular neighborhoods loans were to be denied in, not the creditworthiness of the mortgagor. So it doesn’t seem to be particularly relevant.

          • HeelBearCub says:
            June 1, 2016 at 4:27 pm

            @John Schilling:
            I honest have no idea what you are trying to say. It doesn’t map to anything other than “oooh, sick burn” (into science fiction not fantasy) as near as I can tell.

            @The Nybbler:
            I was responding to this:

            and it is unfair and discriminatory to exclude entire classes people from that just because they historically tend to default on their debtsâ€¦

            My understanding is that the HUD push for lending to minority communities noticed that race, or neighborhood as a proxy for race, was being used instead of strictly monetary criteria. Minorities tended to be rejected for loans by private lenders much in the same way official government redlining used to work, and in fact that the effects of the old, official redlining were still detectable.

          • keranih says:
            June 1, 2016 at 4:31 pm

            As I understand it, redlining did have a rational basis – the assumption that houses in ‘black neighborhoods’ would only be bought by other blacks, who as less wealthy people as a group would be far more likely to default, if they could get a loan at all. Hence offering a loan in that area meant that the bank was assuming a large risk of the owner not being able to sell the home (and pay off the loan) and that the bank would not be able to sell the home in case of foreclosure. Both risks drove up the risk of loaning out money.

            As noted, this was official gubmint policy in the service of standardizing loans. Had the pre-existing bias not been enshrined into regulation we would, I think, have seen what we see now – risk-taking enteripenours gentrifying black and other low value neighborhoods as the market found a meeting place between preceived value and perceived risk.

            Either way, the traditional black neighborhood was never going to last. But a larger chunk of black families would have found stability and wealth along the way.

          • Anonymous says:
            June 1, 2016 at 4:32 pm

            That gets into a pretty touchy issue. If you are an underwriter and you have a huge set of data and when you run you data with a variable for race you get a better fit after accounting for all confounders than when you don’t include it should you be allow to include it?

            Maybe the best answer is no, but in that case there’s a big incentive to find a legally acceptable proxy.

          • Corey says:
            June 1, 2016 at 4:43 pm

            @keranih: Blockbusting was also an interesting issue where individually-rational behavior facilitated discrimination. The way it worked:
            – Speculator hires a black woman or two to walk around a neighborhood with a baby carriage.
            – White residents see this, conclude blacks are moving in, and freak out, selling because they (correctly) assume all their neighbors will also sell.
            – Speculator buys the houses at fire-sale prices.
            – Speculator sells the houses to incoming blacks with “contract lending”, where various random occurrences kick you out of the property and you forfeit your equity.
            – Profit!

          • Eggoeggo says:
            June 1, 2016 at 4:48 pm

            yeaaaah, that sounds like the kind of political myth that gets spread by people who think The Evil Banks want to foreclose on people for a profit/to eat their children.
            Any good citations? Because a “Human Geography” book & “Not in My Neighborhood: How Bigotry Shaped a Great American City” are not exactly confidence-inspiring.

          • Dice Without Rulers says:
            June 1, 2016 at 4:57 pm

            If anything, doesn’t blockbusting sound like the racists are paying a fee for their racism? Whites who benefited from artificially segregated by law housing saw their places drop in value (i.e. they actually had to pay the difference if they wanted whiteness, rather than have it subsidized by people who don’t care or want desegregation) while blacks were able to move into more desirable and less costly housing (relative to the ghettos they were artificially forced to live in by law or by practice). That sounds exactly like how a market solution would quickly resolve imbalances imposed from outside. You might say they were cheating the underpriviledged, but before, blacks couldn’t get housing in the suburbs at any price and as blockbusters would undercut each other (you don’t expect cutthroats to be nice to each other do you?) and eventually reach a new equilibrium probably somewhat higher than before due to increased demand, then drop as more houses are built.

          • keranih says:
            June 1, 2016 at 5:47 pm

            Last I checked, blockbusting wasn’t redlining. And neither was denying loans to credit-worthy applicants, and even that wasn’t subprime lending.

            Is it at all possible to stay anywhere near the topic here?

          • John Schilling says:
            June 1, 2016 at 6:16 pm

            @HeelBearCub: I honest have no idea what you are trying to say.

            Well that makes two of us. My “narrative”, if you insist on calling it that, is that there is a recurring pattern in regulatory affairs where (narratively framed),

            I: A regulation is introduced which protects against risk but stifles productivity,

            II: A class of people or institutions is identified which is observed to act in a low-risk manner,

            III: This class is granted privileged status under the regulation because the productivity loss was getting annoying and we need a low-risk way to get back up to speed,

            IV: It is noticed that some but not all people or institutions are allowed to take advantage of this productivity-enhancing privilege, and on the grounds that this is obviously not fair, the privileged class is expanded.

            V: The new privileged class includes entities whose behavior has traditionally been risky, but are still exempt from the risk-protecting regulatory regime.

            More specifically, we are talking about the regulation of lending risk by way of e.g. mandatory reserve ratios.

            The history of redlining, which does not involve risk-reducing regulatory regimes or privileged regulatory status, seems to me to be irrelevant to any of this. There was, depending on your reference frame, an element of privilege in redlining which was eventually found to be unfair and abolished, but this was as best I can tell an entirely orthogonal axis of privilege which barely intersects the one I am “narrating” and which had differently adverse consequences.

            I made my best guess as to what you were getting at; probably I should not have done that and simply asked you up front. So, what are you trying to say?

          • Jiro says:
            June 2, 2016 at 11:55 am

            If anything, doesnâ€™t blockbusting sound like the racists are paying a fee for their racism? Whites who benefited from artificially segregated by law housing saw their places drop in value (i.e. they actually had to pay the difference if they wanted whiteness

            The endpoint of blockbusting isn’t an integrated neighborhood. So they weren’t paying the difference in cost between a white neighborhood and an integrated neighborhood, they were paying the difference in cost between a white neighborhood and a black neighborhood. That would be a drop in value by too much for your thesis.

      • brad says:
        May 31, 2016 at 12:02 pm

        Sovereign debt (T-Bills in the U.S.) is always, or near always, issued in the official currency of the government.

        It’s not that uncommon for emerging and frontier market countries to issue debt denominated in dollars or euros. A quick google doesn’t provide an easy statistic to point to, but take a look at this article: http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSL6N0N61S220140415

        • HeelBearCub says:
          May 31, 2016 at 12:32 pm

          Yeah, I also note the link provided by youzicha upthread. I overstated my case.

          I do think that it’s pretty unlikely that you see governments described as “developed world” or “1st world” issuing debt denominated in currencies other than their own, for all the reasons I said.

          As to that article, it would not surprise me if we see a spate of articles in the next few years wherein you have various developing world countries sweating their Euro payments due to changes in currency valuation if the Euro strengthens vs. their currency. And then you will have a further spate of articles wherein the European borrowers are sweating the defaults. To some extent, it is just recreating the Greek situation over again, but with economies that are even less stable.

  • Subscribe via Email

  • Advertisements

  • 80,000 Hours researches different problems and professions to help you figure out how to do as much good as possible. Their free career guide show you how to choose a career that's fulfilling and maximises your contribution to solving the world's most pressing problems.

    Seattle Anxiety Specialists are a therapy practice helping people overcome anxiety and related mental health issues (eg GAD, OCD, PTSD) through evidence based interventions and self-exploration. Check out their free anti-anxiety guide here

    .

    Altruisto is a browser extension so that when you shop online, a portion of the money you pay goes to effective charities (no extra cost to you). Just install an extension and when you buy something, people in poverty will get medicines, bed nets, or financial aid.

    Metaculus is a platform for generating crowd-sourced predictions about the future, especially science and technology. If you're interested in testing yourself and contributing to their project, check out their questions page

    B4X is a free and open source developer tool that allows users to write apps for Android, iOS, and more.

    Support Slate Star Codex on Patreon. I have a day job and SSC gets free hosting, so don't feel pressured to contribute. But extra cash helps pay for contest prizes, meetup expenses, and me spending extra time blogging instead of working.

    The COVID-19 Forecasting Project at the University of Oxford is making advanced pandemic simulations of 150+ countries available to the public, and also offer pro-bono forecasting services to decision-makers.

    Norwegian founders with an international team on a mission to offer the equivalent of a Norwegian social safety net globally available as a membership. Currently offering travel medical insurance for nomads, and global health insurance for remote teams.

    AISafety.com hosts a Skype reading group Wednesdays at 19:45 UTC, reading new and old articles on different aspects of AI Safety. We start with a presentation of a summary of the article, and then discuss in a friendly atmosphere.

    Giving What We Can is a charitable movement promoting giving some of your money to the developing world or other worthy causes. If you're interested in this, consider taking their Pledge as a formal and public declaration of intent.

    MealSquares is a "nutritionally complete" food that contains a balanced diet worth of nutrients in a few tasty easily measurable units. Think Soylent, except zero preparation, made with natural ingredients, and looks/tastes a lot like an ordinary scone.

    Jane Street is a quantitative trading firm with a focus on technology and collaborative problem solving. We're always hiring talented programmers, traders, and researchers and have internships and fulltime positions in New York, London, and Hong Kong. No background in finance required.

    Beeminder's an evidence-based willpower augmention tool that collects quantifiable data about your life, then helps you organize it into commitment mechanisms so you can keep resolutions. They've also got a blog about what they're doing here

    The Charter Cities Institute is working on ways governments can set up special zones with unique legal institutions. Learn more about how this could help tackle problems from global poverty to climate change.

    Dr. Laura Baur is a psychiatrist with interests in literature review, reproductive psychiatry, and relational psychotherapy; see her website for more. Note that due to conflict of interest she doesn't treat people in the NYC rationalist social scene.

    The Effective Altruism newsletter provides monthly updates on the highest-impact ways to do good and help others.

    Substack is a blogging site that helps writers earn money and readers discover articles they'll like.
